channel.title: Moparscape's favorite Linux distributions
channel.description:
Well, I want to try out some new Linux Distributions but I don't a very fast connection so I can't just go around and try them all out to see which ones are my thing.
I've tried Ubuntu but it's just too heavyweight for me. It's a bit of a RAM whore and that's not really what I look for in a Linux distro. I've also tried out Fedora 13 (It was awhile ago) which I do like but it has way too much of a corporate feel to it, lacks on all casual feel.
These are the only two I've gotten to experience although I want to try something new. I'm currently downloading Debian (Only 6 hours left.. Awesome.) I just wanted to ask Moparscape what their favorite Linux distribution is, so maybe, I can try it out if you make it sound appealing enough. Also, something that is easy to develop on would be nice.

item.title: Moparscape's favorite Linux distributions
item.dc:creator: @ziplock ziplock
item.description:
@ziplock wrote:

John459:

openSUSE sounds great, but I’ve only used it for server use so far so I haven’t ran it over run level 3. I’ll be installing it on my laptop soon though with gnome, and when that’s done I’ll share my opinion on it.

Can’t wait to hear the outcome. openSUSE looked interesting. I finished the installation of Fedora 15 and it’s a blast. GNOME3 is unlike any desktop environment I’ve ever seen. Of course, I haven’t seen that many. :rolleyes:

Read full topic

item.title: Moparscape's favorite Linux distributions
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

If you like the “feel” of Ubuntu, but not the RAM-whoring, try Xubuntu. The biggest difference is that it uses the XFCE desktop environment, which is very lightweight, but still fully functional.

Read full topic

item.title: Moparscape's favorite Linux distributions

item.description:
@T41 wrote:

Anything with XFCE or fluxbox in their repositories.

item.title: Moparscape's favorite Linux distributions
item.dc:creator: @xryz xryz
item.description:
@xryz wrote:

I beleive the amount of resources the distro take is related to the desktop environment u are using. yes i really like gnome too, but u will probably have to go with a lightweight desktop environment if u dont want the OS hogging memory.

Read full topic

item.title: Moparscape's favorite Linux distributions
item.dc:creator: @ziplock ziplock
item.description:
@ziplock wrote:

krackkid:

I only used RedHat9, So I pick Fedora.

Yeah the’re similar. I didn’t know too many people actually used it, I thought people just developed over it. o.o

[quote=“CoonHunter, post:7, topic:405149”][quote author=Rix_ link=topic=502142.msg3674011#msg3674011 date=1311125490]
Lightweight? Try Crunchbang, it is as bloated as Ubuntu but doesn’t use many resources.

Alternatively you can look at Arch Linux.

[/quote]
Arch does not come with a desktop environment (at least not the one I got) so you will need to know the commands and install a desktop enviroment overtop of it.[/quote]

I’m sure there are some step by step guides that wouldn’t make it too hard to do. GNOME is my favorite so far. I can’t wait to give GNOME 3 a spin. :rolleyes:

Read full topic

item.title: Moparscape's favorite Linux distributions
item.dc:creator: @rip4d rip4d
item.description:
@rip4d wrote:

Only linux distro I’ve used is ubuntu, versions 10.04 & 11.04. I have it on my sisters laptop and dual booted on my desktop.I like it very much with its lightweight feel and the way its set up almost like a smartphone with the app center. I think my uncle uses red hat, but I don’t know much about it.

Read full topic

item.description:

Alternatively you can look at Arch Linux.

item.title: Moparscape's favorite Linux distributions
item.dc:creator: @ziplock ziplock
item.description:
@ziplock wrote:

That does look nice. A light Ubuntu. I just checked out Fedora again and they have a new Fedora 15 with GNOME 3! It looks really awesome and looks like they tried to take out the corporate feel as they even imply it in the description. “Fedora is a fast, stable, and powerful operating system for everyday use”

Read full topic

item.title: Moparscape's favorite Linux distributions
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

If i’m doing a bit of programming I like to use Ubuntu, although I have a laptop I let the family use (when their PC’s are charging or need repair) that has Mint on it. Mint has more of a windows feel and easy o get familiar with. I have also tried lubuntu, it came with ndiswrapper pre-installed so that was a big help when I was setting up my old laptop for sever use. Imo, lubuntu is my favorite desktop oriented linux distro, but I have also not been experimenting with them all either.

Read full topic
